bibl.title: Why did Coptic Fail where Aramaic Succeeded? Linguistic Developments in Egypt and the Near East after the Arab Conquest.
bibl.note: The adoption of Arabic by the Copts was not only the sign of a newly found prosperity and confidence of the community within its country: it also marked the emergence of Egypt as a major independant player in the medieval Mediterranean, and the choice of the Egyptian Christians to participate fully in that phenomenon.
bibl.seg: Arietta Papaconstantinou, Why did Coptic Fail where Aramaic Succeeded? Linguistic Developments in Egypt and the Near East after the Arab Conquest.
Alex Mullen & Patrick James (edd.), Multilingualism in the Graeco-Roman Worlds (Cambridge, 2012) pp. 58-76.

The adoption of Arabic by the Copts was not only the sign of a newly found prosperity and confidence of the community within its country: it also marked the emergence of Egypt as a major independant player in the medieval Mediterranean, and the choice of the Egyptian Christians to participate fully in that phenomenon.
